causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: with decreasing h, the ground-state electronic conﬁguration of the Co atom undergoes two transitions resulting in three different conﬁgurations: high-spin 3d74s2, high-spin 3d84s1, and low-spin 3d94s0 states, respectively.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: lowers the binding energy

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The weaker adsorption strength results also in a higher stretching frequency of the adsorbed molecule, also improving agreement with experiment.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Lower formation energy for Mo dopants
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The formation energy of Mo under Te-rich condition is smaller than that under Te-poor condition.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Easier incorporation of magnetic dopants in Sb2Te3 than Bi2Te3
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Besides, the incorporation of magnetic dopants is easier in Sb2Te3 than that in Bi2Te3.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Reduces formation energy in Bi2Te3, slightly increases it in Sb2Te3
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: We found that the SOC largely reduces the formation energy of Bi2Te3 case (about 43% and 46% for Cr and Mo, respectively) and slightly increases the formation energy of Sb2Te3 case (no more than 8%).

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Smaller formation energy for magnetic dopants in 1QL
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: This difference is expected as structural relaxation around magnetic dopants in 1QL is much easier than that in bulk systems because 1QL system has more free room to relax the stress induced by the dopants.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Suppression of short-range configurations (clustering)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Comparing with Cr doping case (∆𝐸LH*MN*O = 5.4𝑚𝑒𝑉), the energy difference is 48.7meV and 53.8meV for Mo doped Bi2Te3 and Sb2Te3, respectively. The suppression of short-range configurations can largely improve the homogeneity.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Suppressed formation of isolated magnetic clusters
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: In addition, it should be noted that the formation of isolated magnetic clusters can be largely suppressed in thin film comparing to bulk system [26].

determines the sign of the exchange coupling (ferromagnetic vs. antiferromagnetic)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: A ferromagnetic coupling is realized in the range φSO ∈(π/3, 5π/3) while an antiferromagnetic coupling is found in the interval φSO ∈(−π/3, π/3)

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: break the mirror symmetry Mx of the undoped state, favoring the χ = +1 chirality

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The intercalation of adsorbates alters the interaction between hBN on transition metal substrates by electronically decoupling the hBN layer, resulting in a large enhancement of the work function.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Se intercalation at the hBN/Ru interface (below MoSe2)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Modifies the electrostatic potential landscape
causal_relationships.affected_property: Increases MoSe2 band gap and work function, induces band bending.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Se intercalation at the hBN/Ru interface

causal_relationships.affected_property: Influences band gap renormalization, increasing MoSe2 band gap by ~0.26 eV.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The Se intercalation also modifies the dielectric environment, influencing the local band gap renormalization and increasing the MoSe2 band gap by ~0.26 eV.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Higher mole-fraction of In-vacancies
causal_relationships.affected_property: Expected higher jump frequency (if alpha-sublattice vacancy diffusion mechanism is correct)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Mole-fractions of vacancy and antisite point-defects vary monotonically with the composition of a phase.  In particular, the mole-fraction of In-vacancies will be greater in an In-poor sample than in an In-rich one, leading to the expectation of a greater jump-frequency at a given temperature in the In-poor sample than in the In-rich sample for the -sublattice vacancy diffusion mechanism.
causal_relationships.confidence_level: experimentally proven (but contradicted by observed jump frequency trend)

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Higher observed jump frequency (contradicts expectation for alpha-sublattice vacancy mechanism)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As can be seen from the figure, however, relaxation frequencies were much greater in In-rich samples.  Therefore, the simple -sublattice diffusion mechanism can be ruled out by the observed dependence on composition.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Thermally activated transfer of probes from Pd-sites to Eu-sites
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: This is attributed to a thermally activated transfer of probes from Pd-sites to Eu-sites.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Thermally activated transfer of probes from Pr-sites to Pd-sites
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: This indicates a thermally-activated shift in site-preference of In-probes from Pr-sites at low temperature to Pd-sites at high temperature

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Change in rare-earth element in Pd3R
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Dramatic change in site-preference of In from preferring Pd-sites (heavy R) to R-sites (light R). Correlated with increasing relaxation frequency of Cd.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: In summary, it can be seen that the In-impurity has a monotonically changing site-preference from strongly favoring Pd-sites at the Lu-end of the lanthanide series to favoring R-sites at the La-end.... Importantly, it will be argued below that the daughter Cd-probe has a similar monotonic change in site-preference along the series owing to the chemical similarity of sp-elements In and Cd.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Larger lattice parameter (e.g. In3La vs In3Ce/Pr/Nd)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Lower activation enthalpy for interstitial Cd formation
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Presumably, the activation enthalpy for formation of the interstitial (7a) is lower for In3La than for R= Ce, Pr or Nd owing to its larger lattice parameter and a more open structure that can accommodate the interstitial Cd-defect.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increased chemical potential of In, promoting Cd ejection from In-sublattice
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The greater relaxation rate in In-rich than in In-poor In3La may be due to an increased chemical potential for In that serves in effect to “eject” solutes from the In-sublattice.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Re presence at the MoS2 growth front
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increases sulfur vacancy formation energy
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: When Re is present at the growth front of a MoS2 grain, the energy of formation of edge sulfur vacancies is increased by ≈50 kJ/mol.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increases Fermi level
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The slow component reduction may be due to either increased trap filling as a result of the raised Fermi level by Re doping, thereby reducing the concentration of gap states available to assist in the slow recombination processes

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Reduces MoS2 lattice defects
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the 0.1 at.% Re-MoS2 BGFET exhibits a maximum IDS of ≈ 61.5 µA/µm, nearly 10× higher than pristine MoS2 (≈ 7.6 µA/µm), which may be attributed to the reduction in MoS2 lattice defects when Re is introduced to MoS2

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increases impurity scattering
causal_relationships.affected_property: Reduces drain current and mobility by ~30%
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: when the Re content is further increased to 1.0 at.%, the maximum IDS and µFET reduces by nearly 30% due to increasing impurity scattering with more Re in the device channel

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: total hole doping density equal to the moiré density
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: correlated dipolar excitonic insulator
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: a charge insulating state driven by exciton formation

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: holes transferred from moiré layer to WSe2 monolayer
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Under an out-of-plane electric field, the holes can be continuously transferred to the WSe2 monolayer, but remain strongly bound to the empty moiré sites. This is effectively an interlayer exciton fluid

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: tightly bound interlayer excitons
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The interlayer excitons are tightly bound in the limit of low exciton density and 𝑑≪𝑎𝑚.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: charge-incompressible ground state
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Driven by the exciton formation, the ground state is charge-incompressible but exciton-compressible in general

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: varies exciton density
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the exciton density can be continuously varied by the electric field E

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: enhances exciton-exciton correlation
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Compared to exciton fluids in a continuum, the moiré flat bands enhance the exciton-exciton correlation and further stabilize these states.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: holes doped only into moiré layer
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At 𝐸 = -34 mV/nm, holes are doped only into the moiré layer and the monolayer remains charge neutral for the entire doping range

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: 2s exciton loses sensitivity to correlated insulating states
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the 2s exciton loses transition amplitude and sensitivity to correlated insulating states upon doping in the monolayer

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: holes doped into monolayer
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At 𝐸 = -10 mV/nm, the spectra for 𝜈≤1 resemble that of Fig. 1e, f. For 𝜈 > 1, the 1s exciton turns into an attractive polaron (redshifted branch, denoted as X+) and a repulsive polaron (blueshifted branch, not labeled), which signal hole doping into the monolayer.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: holes shared between monolayer and moiré layer before 𝜈𝑚 = 1
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At larger electric fields (𝐸 = 15 and 18 mV/nm), the polaron feature (X+) appears at smaller 𝜈’s (< 1) in the reflection spectrum; accordingly, the extended region of 𝜈𝑚 = 1 emerges at larger 𝜈’s (> 1) in the PL spectrum. In addition, the electron crystal states can no longer be identified. These results support that the holes are now shared between the monolayer and the moiré layer before the density in the moiré layer reaches 𝜈𝑚 = 1.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: holes in monolayer screening extended Coulomb repulsion
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: quantum melting of electron crystal states
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The electron crystal states are quantum melted because the extended Coulomb repulsion in the moiré layer that induces these states are screened by the holes in the monolayer.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: dipolar excitonic insulator at 𝜈 = 1
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: we observe an abrupt energy shift in both the attractive polaron resonance and the PL at total filling 𝜈= 1. This signifies a chemical potential jump and emergence of a new correlated insulating state...The state is consistent with the dipolar excitonic insulator induced by the strong interlayer Coulomb interaction

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: decreased exciton binding energy and weakened excitonic insulator
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The exciton density increases with electric field; the exciton binding energy decreases and the excitonic insulator weaken.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: excitons transition to electron-hole plasma
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The state can no longer be observed (e.g. at 𝐸≳ 30 mV/nm) beyond the exciton Mott density, at which the excitons turn into an electron-hole plasma.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: charge localization and emergence of local magnetic moments in the monolayer
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: we demonstrate charge localization and emergence of local magnetic moments in the monolayer induced by the strong interlayer Coulomb correlation in the excitonic insulating state

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Reduces IAE due to adsorption of airborne contaminants (e.g., water and hydrocarbon molecules)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the measured cohesion energy at the intact homointerfaces is, within our experimental accuracy, independent of the annealing temperatures. However, after exposing the freshly exfoliated 2D crystal flakes to the ambient air, the IAE between similar vdW heterostructures is consistently lower than their corresponding intrinsic value, mainly due to the possible adsorption of airborne contaminants (e.g., water and hydrocarbon molecules) onto the fresh surface of crystals, thereby reducing their overall free surface (Gibbs) energy.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Slightly improves IAE (up to ~5%)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: A mild annealing temperature (130 °C) coupled with relatively strong vdW interactions at the interface can provide a sufficient driving force to push the trapped water molecules away from the contact interface and thus to slightly improve the IAE of the crystals (up to ~5%)

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Nearly full recovery of intrinsic IAE at the hBN homointerface
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: a higher annealing temperature is required to build up larger pressure at the interface to drive out the majority of hydrocarbons as the main source of such IAE drop, leading to nearly full recovery of the intrinsic IAE only at the hBN homointerface upon annealing at 300 °C

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Significantly improves IAE of hBN, G, and MoS2
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Surprisingly, such a precooling treatment can significantly improve the IAE of the hBN, G, and MoS2 crystals regardless of the subsequent annealing temperature.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Further improvement of IAE
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: an increase of the annealing temperature from 130 to 300 °C exhibits further improvement of the IAE, implying that the ice-like layer that is completely removed at T ≤130 °C cannot fully cover the crystal surface, still leaving unprotected areas with adsorbed high boiling point hydrocarbons.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: High annealing temperature (300 °C) in ambient air
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Negative impact on IAE of MoS2/hBN(G)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: unlike very high-quality interface of untreated MoS2/MoS2 upon annealing at 300 °C, the untreated MoS2/hBN(G) interface does not show any further improvement, implying an absent or even negative impact of such a high annealing temperature on the IAE of MoS2/hBN(G). This counterintuitive observation can be explained by a trade-off between interface self-cleansing mechanisms driven by the vdW forces and MoS2 oxidation process triggered by relatively high temperatures (>130 °C) in the ambient air.
causal_relationships.competing_processes: vdW driven self-cleaning vs. MoS2 oxidation

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: No appreciable improvement in IAE of MoS2/hBN(G) at 300°C
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: However, such a protective layer offers no appreciable improvement in the IAE of MoS2/hBN(G) at 300 °C, further confirming the possible destructive effect of interfacial contaminations/oxygen diffusion on the MoS2 oxidation at higher temperatures

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Enhances IAE of G/SiOx interface
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the G crystal tip requires a contact pressure of ≥3 MPa to conform closely to the SiOx surface, thereby enhancing the IAE of the G/SiOx interface

At an estimated highest electron density of 3.0 · 1013
cm−2, induced by the adsorbed potassium atoms, the CBM is populated and the shape of

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote:
In the undoped case... the bands
exhibit the same general features... although they are
noticeably sharper and shifted towards the Fermi energy due to the additional screening
of the Coulomb interaction by the graphene [18]. Furthermore, a replica of the WS2 local
VBM around ¯Γ is noticeable close to ¯Q due to the superlattice formed between graphene

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Potassium doping of graphene on WS2
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Sharp quasiparticle peak at CBM, shake-off bands, reduced linewidths
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote:
Upon doping graphene... the
SL WS2 valence band shifts down in energy and the shape of the VBM does not renormalize
as in the case of bare WS2... The CBM region looks dramatically different... a sharp
quasiparticle peak occurs. The peak is accompanied by a series of replica bands towards
lower kinetic energy, that are conventionally called shake-off bands. The EDC and MDC
linewidths of the main quasiparticle peak are reduced by around a factor of 4, compared to
bare K/WS2

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increased energy separation of shake-off bands proportional to √nG, diminished shake-off intensity relative to quasiparticle peak
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote:
The EDC analysis of the shake-off bands as a function of graphene doping reveals the energy
separation between shake-off bands increases from (50±8) meV to (141±18) meV and that
the increase is proportional to √nG... the EDC fits...
demonstrate that the shake-off band intensity relative to the main quasiparticle
peak diminishes with doping.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Minimizes bandwidth (t) of each vHs

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: When doped near half Moir´e band ﬁlling, the conduction vHs shifts to the Fermi level and an additional correlation-induced gap splits the vHs

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Reduces vHs separation
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The separation between the two vHs’s, which is maximum at charge neutrality and reduced with doping in either direction.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Decreases on-site Coulomb interaction (U)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: U on the other hand is expected to monotonically decrease with smaller angle due to the increased real space unit cell size.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Electron doping

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increased interlayer separation

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increased Tc
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: high levels of electron doping cause a drastic increase in TC by suppressing the AFM arising from the geometric frustration of inequivalent Fe sites.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Changes in electronic density of states near the Fermi level
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As the Stoner model implies, changes in the density of states near the Fermi level would cause considerable changes to the ferromagnetic ordering of FGT.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Decreased magnetic anisotropy
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The mechanism at play may be the contribution of a planar orbital moment component allowing the spins to align along the in-plane direction more easily

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Stronger binding to graphene compared to h-BN.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The stronger binding to graphene is a systematic feature which can be understood considering that the chemisorption of metal adatoms is governed by the following attractive contributions: (i) strong covalent bonding, and (ii) moderate electrostatic interaction as a result of charge transfer between the adatom and the monolayer. While graphene is a semimetal, h-BN is an insulator with a band gap of ≈6 eV. The availability of low-energy electronic states in graphene results in a more efficient interaction with the adatom states and allows for charge transfer between the graphene layer and the adatom, thus introducing an electrostatic component.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Half-filled d-shells in Cr and Mn
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Weak binding of Cr and Mn adatoms to both graphene and h-BN.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Large magnetic moments associated to half-filled d-shell elements correspond to large values of spin splitting of d-electron states and, thus, to their reduced participation to the covalent binding.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Charge transfer from metal substrate to graphene
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Reduces Co adatom binding energy.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the charge transfer from the metal to graphene reduces the charge transfer from the Co adatom to the template surface and, thus, the electrostatic component of the binding energy.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Stronger monolayer-substrate interaction (e.g., Ni substrate vs Cu substrate)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Larger variations of binding energies across the Moiré template.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The Moir´e domains associated with higher binding en-ergies are expected to show larger thermal populations of adatoms, and will thus act as nucleation centers for nanoparticles. Therefore, larger variations of the bind-ing energies across the Moir´e template will favor more ordered nanoparticle arrays with narrower size distribu-tions. We conclude that the templates made of graphene in combination with strongly binding metal surfaces (e.g. Ir, Rh, Ru) are more promising for the self-assembly of metal nanoparticle arrays.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Stripes have linear filling fraction ν ≈ 1/2
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Small doping introduces more stripes at fixed ν reducing the stripe distance d and explaining the observed behavior of the magnetic incommensurability ǫ ≈x with ǫ = 1/(2d)

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: ν = 1 insulating stripes are favored

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: ν starts to grow, d=4
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Further doping occurs at a ﬁxed stripe distance d = 4 and ν starts to grow. This explains the change of behavior observed in both the incommensurability and the chemical potential around doping x = 1/8.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Chemical potential shifts from center of band, breaks particle-hole symmetry
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As discussed above the chemical potential shifts from the center of the band for x > 1/8, thus breaking particle-hole symmetry and consequently both RH and S start to grow in modulus.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: BC stripes and SC stripes become degenerate
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Finally at x ≈0.21 BC stripes and site-centered (SC) stripes be-come degenerate suggesting a regime of soft lateral stripe ﬂuctuations possibly relevant for superconductivity.

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Because of large local strain and lattice rotations, the doping along the 1D boundary differs quite from that of the two adjacent regions, which enables us to realize partially-filled flat bands only in the moiré sites along the 1D boundary.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Changes in the stacking configuration between the two layers of WSe2
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: By applying a STM tip pulse, a nanoscale pit can be generated in the tWSe2 and, simultaneously, nanoscale monolayer WSe2 islands can be observed around the pit, implying that the tip pulses can locally tear the tWSe2 into nanoscale islands... The most pronounced observation in this work is that the stacking configuration between the two layers of WSe2 is changed dramatically around the pit, shown as significant changes in the moiré structure.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Large local lattice rotation (~3.0° ± 0.6°) of the topmost WSe2 around the boundary
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Changes electronic properties of the 1D boundary dramatically
causal_relationships.affected_property: Appearance of sharp peaks at negative energies in dI/dV spectra
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Our atomic-resolved STM measurements and the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) images... reveal that there is a large lattice rotation, ~3.0° ± 0.6°, of the topmost WSe2 around the boundary... implying that electronic properties of the 1D boundary could be quite different from that of its two adjacent regions. Our STS measurement indicates that the electronic properties of the 1D boundary is changed dramatically by the large local lattice rotation: sharp peaks at negative energies are observed in the dI/dV spectra recorded along the boundary...

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Moiré sites on the boundary gain or lose an electron
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Changes Coulomb potential
causal_relationships.affected_property: Electron tunneling rate between STM tip and sample
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: When the moiré sites on the boundary gain or lose an electron, the Coulomb potential changes, altering the electron tunneling rate between the STM tip and the sample. This, in turn, leads to the occurrence of charging and discharging events, resulting in abrupt variations in the STM tunneling current, i.e., the sharp peaks in the STS spectra.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: STM tip approaching the moiré site (increasing tunneling current)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Sharp peak in the dI/dV spectrum shifts towards higher energies
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As the STM tip approaches the moiré site (i.e., with increasing the tunneling current), the sharp peak in the spectrum shifts towards higher energies away from the Fermi level.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Increasing back-gate voltage (from Vg = -20 V to Vg = 16 V)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Tunes one of the flat moiré bands from positive energy to approach the Fermi level
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: With increasing the back-gate voltage from Vg = -20 V to Vg = 16 V, one of the flat moiré bands is tuned from positive energy to approach the Fermi level. Therefore, a smaller negative bias voltage on the tip is enough to bend the flat moiré band to the Fermi level for the charging process...

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Subtle difference of local strain and local lattice rotations on the moiré sites along the boundaries
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Leads to slight differences in the filling between different moiré sites
causal_relationships.affected_property: Energy required for the moiré band to bend to the Fermi level (i.e., the different energies at which the charging peak appears)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: In our experiment, the subtle difference of local strain and local lattice rotations on the moiré sites along the boundaries will lead to slight differences in the filling between different moiré sites, resulting in differences in the energy required for the moiré band to bend to the Fermi level (i.e., the different energies at which the charging peak appears).

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Interlayer shift between graphene and cladding layer

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Constant c1 and c2 at equilibrium (high temperature)

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Decreased desorption rate from surfaces, surface diffusion contributes to edge growth

Meanwhile, the low diffusion energy barrier (0.15 eV on WS2 and 0.22 eV on CdI2) suggests fast diffusion of CdI2 molecules on WS2 and CdI2 layers... Therefore, the CdI2 molecules within the mean-free-path of the edges can arrive and get adsorbed at the edges.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Decreased desorption rate at edges (low temperature)

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The second difference is that the desorption rate of CdI2 molecules at the growth edges also decreases dramatically with decreasing temperature. For in-plane transport, where the spin disorder on Co atoms acts primarily as the scattering source, the amplified coupling under pressure leads to higher resistivity. Conversely, in the c-axis direction, where Co atoms act as bridges between layers, the resistivity decreases as the coupling improves under pressure.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: charge imbalance and emergence of chiral interface states
affects device performance
modifies electron and phonon temperatures
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: An initial sharp increase of Telec is observed within the sub-picosecond regime (~0.5 ps) taking the system above the Curie temperature TC = 68 K2. Tphon follows the variation of Telec as thermal relaxation takes place shortly after the excitation. The behaviour of both temperatures is dependent on the ﬂuence energy applied to the layers displaying variation on the stabilisation of Telec and Tphon towards equilibration. That is, the higher the ﬂuence the larger the stabilised temperatures. This affects directly how the magnetisation (Mz/Ms) responds to the laser pulse, which is strongly ﬂuence-dependent.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: single-step demagnetization (type-I dynamics)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At low ﬂuence magnitudes (e.g., 0.03 mJ cm−2), the demagnetisation process completes before the electron-phonon temperature equilibration is reached (0.34 K). There is a short decay of the magnetisation from the saturation state to Mz/Ms = 0.75 which rapidly recovers on the timescale of ~4 ps.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: two-stage demagnetization process (type-II dynamics)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At higher ﬂuences (i.e., 0.2 mJ cm−2) there is an initial rapid demagnetisation (Mz/Ms = 0.04) of the CrGeTe3 driven by the electron temperature. After the electron-phonon temperature equilibration is achieved (2.25 K) the magnetisation does not signiﬁcantly recover, and instead a second, far slower stage of demagnetisation proceeds which is determined by the phonon temperature.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: formation of magnetic objects (bubbles, spirals, stripes, donuts)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: In this transitional domain, the laser pulse drives the formation of a variety of magnetic objects such as bubbles (circular and elongated), spirals or stripe domains, and donut-shaped textures (e.g., 0.14 mJ cm−2)

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: different types of magnetic textures are created
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: We observed that this phenomenon can be tuned by adjusting the energy ﬂuence applied to the system. That is, different types of magnetic textures can be created in CrGeTe3 with the laser pulse.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: final topological charge is nearly zero, magnetization in type-I dynamics
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At low ﬂuences, 0.001−0.055 mJ cm−2 the ﬁnal topological charge is nearly zero with the magnetisation in the type-I dynamics. This is expected at this weak spin-light interaction regime as the magnetisation recovers to a polarised ferromagnetic (FM) state after a few picoseconds.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: formation of spin stripes
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As the ﬂuence increases within the range of 0.055−0.087 mJ cm−2, the pulse signiﬁcantly demagnetises the system, creating densely packed magnon droplets transiting the system to the formation of non-trivial objects such as spin stripes.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: formation of skyrmions
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The formation of skyrmions however can be achieved as the energy is slightly increased to 0.09−0.180 mJ cm−2. At this limit, the temperature of the system is suitable for the magnon droplets to gain topological features, and hence they evolve into skyrmions rather than merging.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: hybrid spin state of skyrmions, stripes and skyrmioniums
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At ﬂuences above 0.18 mJ cm−2, a hybrid spin state consisting of skyrmions, stripes and skyrmioniums are formed. The large amount of energy deposited in the CrGeTe3 layers at this limit results in thermal ﬂuctuations which are sufﬁcient to inhibit the creation of magnon droplets. Instead, the non-equilibrium spin textures tend to merge and evolve in mixed labyrinthine domains with the appearance of skyrmions and skyrmioniums.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: influences formation of skyrmions or stripe domains
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: A closer look at the magnetisation dynamics reveals that depending on the amount of energy transferred to the layers via the different number of pulses N, the magnon droplets can either be isolated and give place to the formation of skyrmions or magnetic bubbles; or, they can coalesce and form long stripe domains with smaller contributions from localised droplets. We noticed that both situations are possible in CrGeTe3 depending on the number of pulses applied under an external magnetic ﬁeld.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: application of laser pulses combined with magnetic field
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: transformation of magnetic textures
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As laser pulses are applied to CrGeTe3, there are clear transformations of the magnetic textures from one state to another which can be further manipulated via a magnetic ﬁeld.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: switching from stripe-dominant state to random network of magnetic bubbles
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: We then applied N = 100 laser pulses at +25 mT on this state to generate a switching between a stripe dominant-state to a random network of magnetic bubbles.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: controls polarity of created spin textures
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: It is noticed that the polarity reversal of the spin textures with magnetic ﬁelds provides an additional ingredient for controlling on-demand the polarisation of the spin textures or to determine which spin textures are created.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: switch from magnetic bubbles to stripe domains
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: For instance, the switch from magnetic bubbles to stripe domains occurs without the application of magnetic ﬁelds.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: transition from stripes to bubbles
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: However, the transition from stripes to bubbles has been noticed to require a bias ﬁeld.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: reduces the electron doping level
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Annealing the as-made Li1.0(C5H5N)yFe2-zSe2 compound reduces the Tc, from ~44 K to ~39 K

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: reduces pyridine content
raised Tc

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Modifies lattice strain

causal_relationships.affected_property: Marginal increase in Vf; slight decrease in the stiffness and strength of the composites

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Determines the final Mn location: low concentration leads to surface adsorption; increasing concentrations promote inward diffusion and intercalation; very high concentration causes clustering, hindering further diffusion.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: µe != µh (different chemical potentials for electron and hole valleys)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Transitions from a fully gapped VDW state to a non-uniform FFLO state (incommensurate VDW)
causal_relationships.affected_property: Creates ungapped portions of the Fermi surface, leading to metallic conductivity.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As δµ = µe −µh increases, so does this Zeeman splitting, and eventually our ﬁctitious superconducting state approaches to and exceeds the “Chandrasekhar-Clogston” limit, giving way to a non-uniform Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinikov (FFLO) ground state at an incommensurate wavevector q

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: δkF (difference in Fermi wavevectors) exceeding δkc
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Destabilizes the VDW state completely.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Finally, as δkF (x) exceeds certain critical value δkc (xc), the “superconducting” state is completely destroyed and so is the VDW in a true material.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: δkF slightly below  δkc (near the critical value)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Strong VDW fluctuations can induce real superconductivity.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: However, for δkF above but near δkc, we consider strong “superconducting” ﬂuctuations and ﬁnd that these VDW ﬂuctuations can induce real superconductivity in Fe-pnictides

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Introduces real superconductivity
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Thus, if purely electronic interactions are to have a prominent role in generating Fe-based superconductivity of the real world, this eﬀect must arise from HmixedSU(2).

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Enhances the growth of interband scattering W'
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: We notice, however, that G2 enhances the growth of W', thereby giving slight edge to SDW (spin-triplet) over a CDW (spin-singlet).

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Fuels the growth of G2 (interband pair scattering).
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The growth of gW’s fuels the growth of g2 and thus the mixed vertex describing the resonant pair scattering between the hole and electron bands — i.e., the “Josephson” interband vertex c†dc†d + h.c. — becomes strongly enhanced as one approaches the VDW (SDW/CDW/ODW) instability.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Zeeman splitting (difference in hole and electron band sizes)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Cuts off the fictitious "Cooper" divergence.
causal_relationships.affected_property: Leads to "FFLO" state and eventual disappearance of VDW, opening possibility for real superconductivity.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The situation changes, however, when the differences in size between h and e bands are included, i.e., when the “Zeeman splitting” is turned on, by doping or pressure in real FeAs. This cuts oﬀ the ﬁctitious “Cooper” divergence, resulting in our “FFLO” state and eventual disappearance of VDW.
